docs.lead_paragraph: Irving B. Harris, an executive who donated millions of dollars to programs for children's welfare and the arts, died on Saturday at his home here. He was 94. He died after a year of declining health, said P.M. Schuler, a spokesman for the University of Chicago, which received large gifts from Mr. Harris.
docs.abstract: Irving B Harris, executive who donated millions of dollars to arts organizations and programs for children's welfare, dies at age 94 (M)
docs.snippet: Irving B. Harris was an executive who donated millions of dollars to programs for children's welfare and the arts.

docs.lead_paragraph: MANY brands would love to be in Toyota's position: the company's market share is growing and it has a solid reputation for dependability and quality. But as it begins a new national advertising campaign for print and television today, Toyota is hoping to prove that the brand can appeal to a customer's emotional side.

headline.main: Toyota begins a national campaign to highlight more than a vehicle's mere 'rational attributes.'

docs.abstract: Toyota begins national advertising drive that seeks to appeal to auto buyers' emotional side; Toyota marketing official Deborah Wahl Meyer holds people love brand for more than its rational attributes; drive features vignettes about important moments in people's lives (M)
docs.snippet: Toyota is trying to appeal to buyers emotions with a new ad campaign.

docs.lead_paragraph: HOW close can one outfit get to its competition? For the Life Center of Long Island, an anti-abortion counseling group for pregnant women, the answer is directly across the street. Last Sunday, the Life Center formally opened a clinic on the northeast corner of Carmans Road and East Willow Street in Massapequa. On the southeast corner is a clinic operated by Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, which also provides counseling but also two services the Life Center emphatically opposes: abortions and birth control products.
docs.abstract: Article on Life Center for Long Island, anti-abortion counseling group for pregnant woman that has opened clinic in Massapequa opposite one operated by Planned Parenthood of Nassau County; photos (M)
docs.snippet: HOW close can one outfit get to its competition?     For the Life Center of Long Island, an anti-abortion counseling group for pregnant women, the answer is directly across the street. Last Sunday, the Life Center formally opened a clinic on the...

docs.lead_paragraph: 1. Symptoms ''Maybe I am crazy,'' the young woman said, wiping her eyes impatiently. ''All I know is that I throw up whenever I eat, but all the tests say that nothing is wrong. I just don't know anymore.'' The exhausted 26-year-old looked up at the doctor expectantly. Her colorful barrettes and the dark smudges under her eyes gave her the appearance of an irritable child.

headline.main: * Abdominal pain; * Repeated vomiting; * Quickened heartbeat
headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 09-26-04: DIAGNOSIS

docs.abstract: Dr Lisa Sanders Diagnosis column on case of young woman who presents with severe, persistent nausea after eating, with no apparent cause; after thorough investigation by series of doctors, removal of gallbladder appears to have stopped her symptoms; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Sometimes it takes one doctor's persistence to help a desperate patient find relief.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has broken new ground in its ''faith-based'' initiative, this time by offering federal employees a Catholic health plan that specifically excludes payment for contraceptives, abortion, sterilization and artificial insemination. The new plan, announced last week, combines two White House priorities. It is part of a $1 billion project seeking to involve religious organizations in all types of federal social programs. At the same time, the plan is a new form of coverage -- a health savings account combined with high-deductible coverage -- that is being promoted as a centerpiece of President Bush's health care policy.

headline.main: Federal Health Plans to Include One Shaped by Catholic Tenets

docs.abstract: Bush administration offers federal employees Catholic health plan sponsored by OSF Health; plan excludes payment for contraceptives, abortion and other services; is first for federal workers to be marketed as 'faith-based' and is part of $1 billion plan to involve religious organizations in all types of federal social programs; 1984 law prohibits federal plans from covering most abortions, but 1999 law requires plans to cover contraception; 4 million federal employees will have choice of 249 health plans sponsored by dozens of insurers in 2005; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration has broken new ground in its "faith-based" initiative by offering federal employees a Catholic health plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S a rite of passage for many expectant parents: baby's first ultrasound. The fuzzy images of the fetus, produced during an examination in an obstetrician's office, are prized by couples, passed around proudly among friends and relatives. Now, trying to capitalize on this phenomenon, a number of companies are selling elective ultrasounds that have little to do with neonatal health. The services, often in small offices or shopping malls, amount to fetal photo studios and use newer 3-D ultrasound technology to produce more realistic images than conventional machines.
docs.abstract: Some companies are selling elective ultrasound images and video of unborn babies; some doctors and federal regulators feel practice may pose health risks; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Ultrasound images from the womb are increasingly being made not for medical purposes but by companies offering expectant parents a sort of prebirth viewing.
